defs.docs: ed25519 signatures and verification

attributes.value: / Creating an ed25519 signature on a message is simple.
/ First, we need to generate a `Keypair`, which includes both public and
/ secret halves of an asymmetric key.  To do so, we need a cryptographically
/ secure pseudorandom number generator (CSPRNG), and a hash function which
/ has 512 bits of output.  For this example, we'll use the operating
/ system's builtin PRNG and SHA-512 to generate a keypair:
/ We can now use this `keypair` to sign a message:
/ let message: &[u8] = "This is a test of the tsunami alert system.".as_bytes();
/ As well as to verify that this is, indeed, a valid signature on
/ # let message: &[u8] = "This is a test of the tsunami alert system.".as_bytes();
/ Anyone else, given the `public` half of the `keypair` can also easily
/ # let message: &[u8] = "This is a test of the tsunami alert system.".as_bytes();
/ into byte-arrays by calling `.to_bytes()`.  It's perfectly acceptible and
/ safe to transfer and/or store those bytes.  (Of course, never transfer your
/ secret key to anyone else, since they will only need the public key to
/ # let message: &[u8] = "This is a test of the tsunami alert system.".as_bytes();
/ And similarly, decoded from bytes with `::from_bytes()`:
/ # use ed25519_dalek::{Keypair, Signature, PublicKey, SecretKey, SignatureError};
/ # fn do_test() -> Result<(SecretKey, PublicKey, Keypair, Signature), SignatureError> {
/ # let message: &[u8] = "This is a test of the tsunami alert system.".as_bytes();
/ If you prefer the bytes to be wrapped in another serialisation format, all
/ types additionally come with built-in [serde](https://serde.rs) support by
/ They can be then serialised into any of the wire formats which serde supports.
/ # let message: &[u8] = "This is a test of the tsunami alert system.".as_bytes();
/ recipient may deserialise them and verify:
/ let message: &[u8] = "This is a test of the tsunami alert system.".as_bytes();

attributes.value: / Afterwards, you can generate the corresponding publicprovided you also
/ supply a hash function which implements the `Digest` and `Default`
/ traits, and which returns 512 bits of outputvia:
/ The standard hash function used for most ed25519 libraries is SHA-512,
/ which is available with `use sha2::Sha512` as in the example above.
/ Other suitable hash functions include Keccak-512 and Blake2b-512.
/ A CSPRNG with a `fill_bytes()` method, e.g. `rand::ChaChaRng`

defs.name: ExpandedSecretKey
defs.docs: An "expanded" secret key.

attributes.value: / This is produced by using an hash function with 512-bits output to digest a
/ `SecretKey`.  The output digest is then split in half, the lower half being
/ the actual `key` used to sign messages, after twiddling with some bits. The
/ upper half is used a sort of half-baked, ill-designed pseudo-domain-separation
/ "nonce"-like thing, which is used during signature production by
/ concatenating it with the message to be signed before the message is hashed.

attributes.value: / Convert this `ExpandedSecretKey` into an array of 64 bytes.

/ secret key, and the last 32 bytes represent the "domain-separation"

/ * `prehashed_message` is an instantiated hash digest with 512-bits of
/   output which has had the message to be signed previously fed into its
/ * `public_key` is a [`PublicKey`] which corresponds to this secret key.
/ * `context` is an optional context string, up to 255 bytes inclusive,
/   which may be used to provide additional domain separation.  If not
/   set, this will default to an empty string.

attributes.value: / Verify a `signature` on a `prehashed_message` using the Ed25519ph algorithm.
/ * `prehashed_message` is an instantiated hash digest with 512-bits of
/   output which has had the message to be signed previously fed into its
/ * `context` is an optional context string, up to 255 bytes inclusive,
/   which may be used to provide additional domain separation.  If not
/   set, this will default to an empty string.
/ * `signature` is a purported Ed25519ph [`Signature`] on the `prehashed_message`.
/ Returns `true` if the `signature` was a valid signature created by this

/ `SECRET_KEY_LENGTH` of bytes is the `SecretKey`, and the next
/ `PUBLIC_KEY_LENGTH` bytes is the `PublicKey` (the same as other
/ libraries, such as [Adam Langley's ed25519 Golang

defs.name: from_bytes
defs.docs: Construct a `Keypair` from the bytes of a `PublicKey` and `SecretKey`.

attributes.value: / Construct a `Keypair` from the bytes of a `PublicKey` and `SecretKey`.
/ * `bytes`: an `&[u8]` representing the scalar for the secret key, and a
/   compressed Edwards-Y coordinate of a point on curve25519, both as bytes.
/ Absolutely no validation is done on the key.  If you give this function
/ bytes which do not represent a valid point, or which do not represent
/ corresponding parts of the key, then your `Keypair` will be broken and
/ A `Result` whose okay value is an EdDSA `Keypair` or whose error value
/ is an `SignatureError` describing the error that occurred.

defs.name: generate
defs.value:
pub fn generate<D, R>(&mut R) -> Keypair where D: Digest<OutputSize = U64> +
Default, R: CryptoRng + Rng
defs.docs: Generate an ed25519 keypair.

attributes.value: / A CSPRNG with a `fill_bytes()` method, e.g. `rand::ChaChaRng`.
/ The caller must also supply a hash function which implements the
/ `Digest` and `Default` traits, and which returns 512 bits of output.
/ The standard hash function used for most ed25519 libraries is SHA-512,
/ which is available with `use sha2::Sha512` as in the example above.
/ Other suitable hash functions include Keccak-512 and Blake2b-512.

defs.name: sign_prehashed
defs.value:
pub fn sign_prehashed<D>(&Self, D, Option<&'static [u8]>) -> Signature where
D: Digest<OutputSize = U64> + Default
defs.docs:
Sign a `prehashed_message` with this `Keypair` using the
 Ed25519ph algorithm defined in [RFC8032 5.1][rfc8032].

attributes.value: / Sign a `prehashed_message` with this `Keypair` using the
/ * `prehashed_message` is an instantiated hash digest with 512-bits of
/   output which has had the message to be signed previously fed into its
/ * `context` is an optional context string, up to 255 bytes inclusive,
/   which may be used to provide additional domain separation.  If not
/   set, this will default to an empty string.
/ let message: &[u8] = b"All I want is to pet all of the dogs.";
/ // Create a hash digest object which we'll feed the message into:
/ If you want, you can optionally pass a "context".  It is generally a
/ good idea to choose a context and try to make it unique to your project
/ and this specific usage of signatures.
/ For example, without this, if you were to [convert your OpenPGP key
/ to a Bitcoin key][terrible_idea] (just as an example, and also Don't
/ Ever Do That) and someone tricked you into signing an "email" which was
/ actually a Bitcoin transaction moving all your magic internet money to
/ their address, it'd be a valid transaction.
/ By adding a context, this trick becomes impossible, because the context
/ is concatenated into the hash, which is then signed.  So, going with the
/ previous example, if your bitcoin wallet used a context of
/ "BitcoinWalletAppTxnSigning" and OpenPGP used a context (this is likely
/ the least of their safety problems) of "GPGsCryptoIsntConstantTimeLol",
/ then the signatures produced by both could never match the other, even
/ if they signed the exact same message with the same key.
/ Let's add a context for good measure (remember, you'll want to choose
/ # let message: &[u8] = b"All I want is to pet all of the dogs.";

/   output which has had the message to be signed previously fed into its
/ * `context` is an optional context string, up to 255 bytes inclusive,
/   which may be used to provide additional domain separation.  If not
/   set, this will default to an empty string.
/ * `signature` is a purported Ed25519ph [`Signature`] on the `prehashed_message`.
/ Returns `true` if the `signature` was a valid signature created by this
/ let message: &[u8] = b"All I want is to pet all of the dogs.";
/ // The sha2::Sha512 struct doesn't implement Copy, so we'll have to create a new one:

defs.name: SignatureError
defs.docs: Errors which may occur while processing signatures and keypairs.

attributes.value: / Errors which may occur while processing signatures and keypairs.
/ This error may arise due to:
/ * Being given bytes with a length different to what was expected.
/ * A problem decompressing `r`, a curve point, in the `Signature`, or the
/ * A problem with the format of `s`, a scalar, in the `Signature`.  This
/   is only raised if the high-bit of the scalar was set.  (Scalars must
/ * Failure of a signature to satisfy the verification equation.
